list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

sense.s: l — lanaA fiI baniI fulaAnK dimaMCN [We have a claim, upon the sons of such a one, to blood, lit. bloods]. (S in art. xbl.)
lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA He shall have a right to do such a thing: see Eaqaba.

raOayotu lahu bariyqFA I saw it to have a glistening: and samiEotu lahu SawotFA I heard him, or it, to have a sound proceeding from him, or it; or rather, I heard a sound attributable, or to be attributed, to him, or it; meaning, I heard him, or it, utter or produce, a sound; or I heard in consequence of it, &c. (see saTaEN).
lahu kacaA often means Such a thing appertains, or is attributable, to him, or it.

maA lanaA OalRaA nuqaAtila, in the Kur ii. 247, [i. e. Oano laA,] means What object have we (OaIRu garaDK lanaA) in (fiI) [that we should not fight? or, in our] not fighting? (Bd:) And maA lanaA OalRaA natawakRala EalaI QllRehi, in the same, xiv. 15, means What excuse have we (OaIRu EucorK lanaA) in (fiI) [that we should not rely upon God? or, in our] not relying upon God? (Bd.) maA lanaA Oano laA nafoEala kacaA [may be rendered What reason, or motive, have we that we should not do such a thing? or, in that, &c.? or in our not doing &c.? for] the original form of the phrase is maA lanaA fiI Oano laA nafoEala kacaA (Mugh, voce Oano.) Often Oano is omitted, but meant to be understood: you say also, maA laka tafoEalu kacaA What reason, or motive, hast thou that thou dost such a thing? or what aileth thee &c.? It is often like maA baAluka.
garRada biSawotK lahu DaEiyfK It (a bird) warbled with a feeble voice peculiar to it.
maA liI walilobagi baEoDikumo EalaI baEoDi: see maA liI OaraAka tafoEalu kacaA bagaI What hath happened to me that I see thee doing such a thing, or thus? See an ex. in conj. 3 of art. blw.
maA laka bikacaA: see a verse cited in art. Elw.
OanaA lahaA I am for it; i. e., I am the man for it; meaning a war, or battle, HarobN, which is of the fem. gender. Often occurring in old Arabic stories.
li in the sense of fiI: see Msb, voce EidRapN.
mano liI Who is, or will be, for me, as aider, or helper, or defender, or surely? For exs., see saboEN, and Xabara, and OafovaOa.
taEosFA lahu, and quboHaA lahu, and natonFA lahu, &c.: see the first word of each of these phrases.
mano liI bikacaA: see bi (near the end of the paragraph): and see also above.
li in the sense of baEod: see an ex. voce OafoTara, and see other exs. in the Msb, art. fTr.
li in the sense of baEoda, or mino waqoti: see gamRN.
lilayolapK xalato When one night had passed; i. e. on the first day of the month: l in this case meaning Einoda.
yaA lilofaliyqapi come with succour to the calamity: see filoqN.
li in the sense of EalaI: see Kur xvii. 108-9, and xvii. 7, and xxxvii. 103: and see exs. voce fuwhN (last quarter).
l in fadFI laka &c.: see art. fdI.

la used as a corroborative, (see S in art. lwm,) after lawo and luwolaA the conditional Uino, is sometimes difficult to express in English, except by emphasis in pronunciation; as in OamaA UinRahu larajulN kariymN Verily, or now surely, he is a generous man. This ex. occurs voce OamaA.
la redundantly prefixed, for corroboration, to the k of comparison: see a verse of Tarafeh voce vinoIN; and another similar instance in the Mugh, art. l.

laZarufa zayodN means How excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, or the like, is Zeyd! syn. maA OaZorafahu: and lakaruma EamorNw How generous, &c., is Amr! syn. maA Oakoramahu. (Mugh.)
laniEoma huwa Excellent indeed is he, or it.

maA kaAna liyafoEala means, accord. to the Koofees, maA kaAna yafoEalu; the l being redundant, to corroborate the negation: accord. to the Basrees, maA kaAna qaASidFA liOano yafoEala. (Mugh.) See an ex. voce EalaI as equivalent to fiI.
la in sentences beginning with Uino for UinRa: see p. 107, cols. 2 and 3: and see conj. 3 in art, qrO.
l of inception (laAmu AlUibotidaMCi): see exs. of this voce UinRa: and see De Sacy's Gr. Ar. n. 582, &c.
la termed laAmu AljawaAbi is, I think, best rendered by Then; or in that case: see exs. voce OamaA.

la in laEamoru QllRehi is [not a particle denoting swearing, but merely] a corroborative of the inchoative; the enunciative of which, i. e. qasamiI, or maA Ouqosimu bihi, is understood. (S, art. Emr.)

yaA lazayodK, and yaAla zayodK, accord. to the Koofees, is a contraction of yaA Mla zayodK. (Mugh, letter l; and El-Ashmoonee on the Alfeeyeh, AlAstfAvp.) It seems that where the l is not connected with the word following it, yaAla is generally, if not always, for yaA Mla; and so sometimes when it is connected. See yaAla gudara, voce gaAdirN, and see EajabN. See also De Sacy's Gr. Ar., 2nd ed., i. 476, note.

laA, the negative, does not necessarily restrict to the signification of future time a marfooa aor. following it: in a case of this kind, maA is often substituted for it in the explanation of a phrase; as in the instance of laA yaEorifu hirRaA mino birRK, in the TA, art. br; and the aor. is more properly rendered by the present than by the future.

laA rajula qaAYimN There is not any man standing: (Mugh:) but when the subst. and epithet are both simple words, and not separated, the latter may be used in three different ways; as in laA rajula Zariyfa and ZariyfFA and ZariyfN; otherwise it must be marfooa or mansoob, but not mebnee: this relates to lA used linafoIi Aljinosi. (Ibn-'Akeel, p. ???.)
lA, also, Lest. See rakabahu.

[laA lahu walaA Ealayohi There is nothing due to him, nor anything to be demanded of him. (Thus I have rendered this phrase, voce malasaI, in three places.) For] when lA is a general negative, the context renders it allowable to suppress its subject, as in laA Ealayoka, for laA baOosa Ealayoka; and sometimes the predicate, when known, is suppressed, as in laA baOosa. (Msb.)
laAXa, for laA XaIoCa: see art. lwX.
kalaA walaA [As the time occupied in saying laA walaA]. See an ex. in the TA, voce lwocaAn.
laA walaA Olive-oil: in allusion to the words in the Kur xxiv. 35, occurring in a trad.
laA yaqoraOi, as a prohibition, and lA yaqoraOu as an enunciative with the same meaning: see a trad. thus commencing in the Jámi' es-Sagheer: and see the Kur lvi. 78: and see an ex. voce rahonN.
laA OagarRu walaA bahiymN: see bahiymN.
laA in a case of pausation pronounced laOo: see art. A (near the end).
1. laOaka He sent. (Msb in art. Alk.)
OalikoniI Uilayohi; and Oalakotuhu: see art. Alk.
10. AisotaloOaka: see AstOlk.
maloOakN: see maOolakN.
laORlN: see art. lO.
liYaAlapN: see art. lO.
1. laWuma He was base, base-born, low, ignoble, ungenerous, mean, sordid; (S:) contr. of karuma. (K.) See laYiymN.
laOama: see also ZaAhara.
3. laMCamotu bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. mulaMCamapN, I reconciled the people, (S, Msb,) and brought them together. (S.)
laMCamahu He was suited to him as a companion: see 5 in art. zwI.
laMCamahu It (food, T, and an affair, M) suited him. (T, M.)
And i. q. laA zamahu. (T.)
And It coalesced, or united, with it.
8. AilotaOama It (a wound, and a crack) became coalesced, consolidated, closed, or closed up: (S:) it (a hole, or rent,) became repaired. (Msb.)
AilotaOamaA They (two things) agreed together, or became consistent. (S, Msb.)
AilotaOama It drew, and stuck, together; coalesced; or consolidated. (Mgh.)
luWomapN: see luWamapN.

luWamapN, (S, K,) or luWomapN↓, (M, IB,) The whole apparatus, or gear, of the plough: (AHn, S, M, K:) or its iron [or share] and its wooden parts: (M:) or the sinRap [or ploughshare] with which the earth is ploughed up, and which, when upon the plough, is termed EiyaAnN, pl. Eyn: (IAar, TA:) the sikRap. (IB, TA.) See EiyaAnN.
rajulN jamiyEu AllRaOomapi: see jamiyEN.
laYiymN Mean; ungenerous; sordid; ignoble; base; base-born; contr. of kariymN. (K, &c.) See laWuma.
OalaAYimu AlOumuwri: see madaAqR.
OaloOamu Baser, and basest; &c.: see an ex. voce zakomapN.
AlmulaMCamapu i. q. AlAijotimaAEu: see Aisotalama.
riyXN mutalaAYimN i. q.. luWaAmN. See lafata.
baEodu laOoIK After difficulty, &c. (Lth, TA.) See an ex. cited voce bayRana.
laOoyFA With difficulty, trouble, labour, or exertion.
mulabRasN pl. mulabRasaAt Sugared almonds, &c.
laboEFA: see DaboEN.
EabiqN labiqN and EabiqapN labiqapN: see EabiqN.
labiqN baAlqaluwbi: see EaciqN.
labaAqapN: see UinaAqapN in art. Anq.
1. labakahu is like rabakahu.
labakapN: see EabakapN.
labolaAbN: see HilibolaAbN or HilobaAbN.
banaAtu labanK [app. The small guts or intestines, in which originate the lacteals;] the intestines in which is the milk. (M, K.) See HawyRapN, termed banaAtu AllRabani.
labanapN [n. un. of labanN]. (Az, in TA, art. xrs.)
labinN Bricks; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) crude, or unburnt, bricks. (MA.)
libonapN: see baniyqapN.

lubaAnN [The frankincense-tree] is a tree of the kind called EiDaAh, having a fruit resembling the pistachio-nut, and a resin like the kunodur, [which is said in the S and TA to be the same as the lubaAn,] when it concretes: (O and TA in art. syE:) it is also, and more commonly, applied to the resin itself, i. e. frankincense, or olibanum: the tree that produces it is now known to be of the genus Boswellia, found in Hadramowt and other parts of Southern Arabia, and also in the opposite (eastern) region of Africa, and in India: it was formerly erroneously supposed to be the Juniperus Lycia.
HaSaI lubaAnK: see K, voce EasalN; and see art. HSI.
libaAnN The sucking of milk or of the breast: (S, Msb, K:) see an ex. in a verse of El-Aashà cited voce OasoHamu: and see 1 in art. gcw.
labuwnN: see laquwHN and bakorN.
Uibonu labuwnK A male camel that has entered upon his third year: (S, Mgh, K:) or entering upon his third year: (Msb:) or in his second year. (K.)
Easalu AllRubonaI i. q. AlmayoEapu [now applied to Storax, or styrax] sometimes used for fumigation. (TA.) See art. Esl.
lubaAnapN magoribiyRapN: see farobayuwnN.
labaniyRapN Food made with milk: so in modern Arabic: see xaTiyfapN.
lubayonapN [A little milk: dim. of labanapN, n. un. of labanN]: see ravaOa.
milobanN A thing like the miHomal, upon which bricks (labin) are carried from place to place. (M.) See fatoxaMCu.
2. labRaAhu [inf. n. talobiyapN] He said to him labRayok. (MA.)
labRayoka, and labRayohi, and labRaIo yadayoka: see art. lb.
livapN The gum. See art. lwv.

luvofapN The changing, in pronunciation, s into v, or r into g or l, (S, K, Msb,) and the like: (Msb:) or, one letter into another. (Az, in Msb, K.) Also, A word mispronounced; as when a word is said to be lugapN Oawo luvofapN a dialectal variant or a word mispronounced.
1. lavamati AlHijaArapu xufRa AlbaEiyri The stones wounded the camel's foot, and made it bleed. (S.)
lavamato. She muffled herself with a livaAm. (K.)
livaAmN A kind of muffler for the mouth. (K.)
lavFI: see Eabiybap.
AlHuruwfu AllRitawiyRapu [The gingival letters:] these are c v, and Z. (TA, commencement of bAb AlvAC.)
1. laj fiI AlOamori He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing; he was persevering, or assiduous, in the affair. (Msb.)
lajafo: see qiSaAbN.
4. Oalojama He bridled a beast; agreeably with an explanation in the K: and sometimes he bitted him; as expl. in the Msb.
5. talajRamato: see 10 in art. vfr.
lujamN: see lujomapN.

lujomapN and lijaAmN↓ A thing from which one augurs evil; an omen, or a bodement, of evil: because it refrains one from a thing that he wants. (A, art. ETs.) lujamN↓, which is originally the plural of both, is also used as a sing. (A, ibid, where see an ex.) See EaTasa and EaTuwsN.

lijaAmN [A bit; i. e., the iron appurtenances of a bridle]. To the ljAm belong pieces of iron which are fastened one to another; as the EiDaAdataAni, and the misoHal, and the faOos and its extremities of iron. (Az, in TA, voce qayoqabN.) The above explanation is incomplete: it means the bridle, or headstall and reins, with the bit and other appurtenances; like its Persian original, likaAmo: see qarRaTa. It signifies The piece of iron in the mouth of the horse: thus, by extension, applied to this with its thongs, or straps, and apparatus: it comprises the Xakiymap, which is the transverse piece of iron in the mouth; and the faOos, which is the piece of iron standing up in the mouth; and the misoHal, which is the iron beneath the Hanak; and the xuTRaAfaAni, which are two bent pieces of iron in the misoHal and the Xkymp, on the right and left; and the faraAXataAni, which are two pieces of iron wherewith are fastened the extremities of the EicaAraAni; and the Hakamap, which is the ring surrounding the marosain and the Hanak, of silver or iron or thong. (IDrd, in his Book on the Saddle and Bridle.)
See lujomahN.
1. lajina: see lajica.
5. talajRana AlnRabaAtu: see talazRaja.
laHoZN: see EayorN.
liHaAfN: see what follows.

miloHafapN A mulaMCap that is sumuT [not lined, nor stuffed]: if lined or stuffed, the vulgar also call it by this name, but the Arabs do not know this: (L, TA:) and the same applies to the liHaAf↓: Az says, that liHaAfN and miloHafN mean the same: like UizaArN and miYozarN, and qiraAmN and miqoramN; and sometimes one says miqoramapN and miloHafapN; and it is the same whether the garment be sumuT or lined. (TA.) He says also, [in another place,] that the Arabs apply the terms liHaAfN↓ and miloHafapN to A night-wrapper (UizaAru layoli) if it be TaAqN waAHidN [a single piece of stuff; i. e. not double, not lined nor faced, nor stuffed]. (TA in art. smT.)
See UizaAzN.
1. laHiqahu laHiqa bihi and OaloHaqahu↓ He reached him; overtook him; or came up with him. (S, Msb, K.)
laHiqahu It (grief, &c.) overtook him; or ensued to him.
Also, and laHiqa bihi He overtook him; came up with him.
laHiqa bihi He became, or made himself, on a par, or as though on a par, with him. See an ex. voce tawaHRaXa.
It became adjoined, or annexed, to it.
luwHka↓ It was firmly, or strongly, compacted or coherent or knit together: and its several parts were inserted one into another. (TA.)
laHiqahu AlvRamanu, inf. n. luHuwqN, [i. q. Oadorakahu, i. e. The payment of] the price was, or became, obligatory on him. (Msb.)
laHiqato quwRatuhu wasinRuhu: see the last sentence of art. Ewn.
laHiqahu has for its inf. n. luHuwqN as well as laHaAqN. (TA.)
3: see 1.

4. OaloHaqahu bihi He made him to reach, overtake, or come up with, him; (S, Msb, * K; *) or to follow him. (Msb.) He made it (a punishment) to [overtake him, or] befall him. (Msb.) He removed him to it; namely, a place; lit., caused him to reach it: see an ex. voce xaAfiqN.
He affiliated him to him; announced him to be his son, because of a mutual likeness. (Msb.)
OaloHaqahu bihi He classed him, as an adjunct, with him; put him on a par with him; or made him to be as though on a par with him; See two exs. voce laATa, in art. lyT.
See 1.
6. talaA Haqati AlmaTaAyaA The saddle-camels overtook one another. (S, K.) talaA HaquwA The last of them overtook, or came up with, the first of them. (S, TA in art. drk.)
luHuwqN i. q. luzuwmN and luSuwqN. (TA)
laAHiqu AlMTaAli Lean, or lank, in the sides. (Ham. p. 496.) laAHiqu AlbaToni Lank in the belly. (TA in art. rhf.)

UiloHaAqN The rendering a word quasi-coördinate to another word of which the radical letters are more in number than those of the former word. A letter which is added to a word for the purpose above mentioned. See Oalifu AlUiloHaAqi and Oalifu AltRakoviyri in art. A.
Harofu UiloHaAqK A letter of adjunction, or quasi-coördination.
muloHaqN, pl. muloHaqaAtN, A word rendered quasiradically coördinate to another word of which the radical letters are more in number than those of the former word.
See UiloHaAqN.
birawocawonN mutalaAHikN i. q. mutaEaAwinN. (TA in art. Ewn.)
4. OaloHama xaroqahu [He closed up the hole thereof with a patch]; meaning a garment, or piece of cloth, and a skin, or hide. (TA in art. rqE.)
UiloHaAmu AljiraAHaAti [The consolidating of wounds]. (K in art. sbE.)

OaloHamahu EiroDahu (tropical:) He empowered him to revile, vilify, or censure, him: (S, K, TA:) he made his honour, or reputation, to be to him [as] a luHomap↓ [or hawk's portion of the quarry]. (Har, p. 392.)
OaloHimo maA Oasodayota: see OasodaI.
6. talaAHama It was joined, or knit, together. See K, voce mazofuwrN.
8. AilotaHama It coalesced, consolidated, closed up, or became closely united. (TA.)
tamorN lahu laHomN [Dates having flesh]. (Msb in art. HXf.)
laHomN: see variydN, last sentence.
XaHimN laHimN: see maHiDN and XaHimN.
laHomapN and luHomapN↓ The woof; or the threads that are woven into the sadaI. or warp, of a piece of cloth. (Msb, &c.)
luHomapN: see 4, and laHomapN.
luHomapN XaAbikapN: see muXotabikN.
laHRaAmN A butcher. (Fr, TA in art. sTr.)

malaAHimu Alfaroji (K) The narrow, or strait, parts of the pudendum muliebre: (TA:) or rather, the fleshy parts thereof: the sing. maloHamapN signifying, accord. to analogy, a place of much flesh: see biTaAnN.
AlmulotaHimapN [The tunica albuginea, or white of the eye: so in the present day]. (K, voce sabalN.)
XajRapN mutalaAHimapN: see XajRapN, and baAzilapN (voce baAzilN).
1. laHana He erred in speech; spoke incorrectly. (Msb.)
laHana lahu He said to him something which he (the latter) understood, but which was unintelligible to others: (Az, S, Msb, K:) he intimated to him something which he (the latter) alone understood.
3. laAHanahumo i. q. faATanahumo. (S, K.) See an ex. voce jaAmiEN; and see my explanations of mufaATanapN.

laHonN The meaning of speech; its intended sense or import: (S, K, TA:) its intent: (TA:) [it is direct: and also indirect:] an indication thereof whereby the person addressed is made to understand one's intent; so says Az (Msb: [and the like is said in the TA on the authority of AHeyth:]) an oblique, or ambiguous, mode of speech: (Msb:) an inclining of speech to obliqueness, or ambiguity, and equivocal allusion. (Bd, in xlvii. 32.)
Earafotuhu fiI laHoni kalaAmihi and fI naHowi klAmh. and fI miEoraADi klAmh signify the same. (Msb in art. ErD.) See the last of these voce EaruwDN.
laHonN A modulated sound; expl. as being mina AlOaSowaAti AlmaSuwgapi AlmawoDuwEapi: pl. OaloHaAnN and luHuwnN. (K.) You say, OaloHaAnu AlOagaAniI [The modulated sounds of songs]. (Mgh.)
1. luHiIa: see a verse cited voce xaTaba.
laHaAhu QllRehu: see XaraAhu.
5. talaHRaI, (S, Mgh,) and tlHRI biEimaAmatihi, (TA, art. Ejr,) He wound a part of his turban under his lower jaw: (S, Mgh:) as also taHanRaka, q. v.
8. AilotaHayotu AllRaHoma Eani AlEaZomi [I peeled off the flesh from the bone]. (O, K, in art. slq.)
laHoIN [not laHFI] The jaw-bone; (Mgh, Msb;) either upper or lower: (Msb:) and, in a man, (Msb,) the part on which the beard grows. (S, Msb, K.)
And sometimes Either lateral portion of the lower jaw: see caqanN, and Alfaniyku.
liHoyapu AltRayosi: see viylN.
liHoyapN is sometimes, by a synecdoche, put for the whole person: see a verse cited voce xunovN.
masoHu AllRuiHaI: see EaqRa biAlsRahomi.
liHaMCN Bark; and in particular the bark of a plant, or of a tree, of which ropes &c. are made.
The liHaMC of the date is [its Pulp, pulpy pericarp, or flesh; i. e.] the part that clothes the nawaAp [or stone]. (TA.)
liHaMCu AlEinabi [The skin of grapes]. (TA in art. XHm.)
lawaAHiI AlXRayobi, for lawaAYiHu AlXyb, q. v.

luxoquwqN [A sort of trench, or channel, made by water, which has worn and undermined its sides;] a place in which water flows, having sides worn and undermined thereby, and hollowed in the form of the river, or river-bed: pl. laxaAqiyqu. (ISh, TA.)
OaloxaI Distorted in the mouth. (CK; L, art. lx, but written AlxMC.)
muladRamN A garment, or piece of cloth, patched, or pieced; or patched, or pieced, in several places; like muradRamN. (Lth, T, in art. rdm.)

s.hi: Supple; lithe; limber; limp; pliant; pliable; flexible.

sense.s: mino laduno From the time of: see a verse cited in art. EI, conj. 4.
hecaA AlOamoru mino ladunohu i. q. mino qibalihi, q. v. (Lth in TA, in art. qbl.)
1. lacaEa AllRisaAna [It burned the tongue; was acrid]. (S, Msb, art. Hrf; &c.)
lacoEu Albarodi [The hurting, or paining, of cold]. (S, O, K, voce XafiyfN.)
3. laAzRahu i. q. DaAyaqahu. (TA, voce caAqanahu.)
lazRN i. q. zurofiynN. (A, K.) In the CK, walazazN qayonN is a mistake for waAllRazRu AlzRurofiynu.
lizoqahu and biluziqihi Close by his, or its, side.
1. lazimahu It necessarily, or inseparably, belonged, or pertained, or it clave, or adhered, to him, or it; as also lazima lahu: it (disgrace, &c.) attached to him.
lazimahu Oamoru fulaAnK The management of the affair, or affairs, of such a one was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, upon him.
lazima XayoYFA He kept close, clave, clave fast, clung, or held fast, to anything. (S, K, &c.) And hence, He preserved a thing: see qaniIa.
See 3.
lazma Algariyma, and lazima bihi, and laAzamahu↓, He adhered, kept, clave, clung, or held fast, to the debtor. (Msb.)
lazima bayotahu He kept, or clave, to his house or tent; did not quit it; was not found elsewhere. (Kull, p. 318.)
lazimahu AlmaAlu The [paying of the] money &c. behoved him, lay on him, was incumbent on him, or obligatory on him. (Msb.)
3. laAzamahu He kept, confined himself, clave, clung, or held fast, to him, or it: as also lazimahu↓: he held on, or continued, it. See 1.

4. Oalozamahu XayoYFA signifies He necessitated him, or obliged him, to do, and to pay, &c.; or to suffer, or endure, a thing: and hence, said of God, He decreed; or appointed, or ordained, to him a thing. And He made him to cleave to a thing; and he made a thing to cleave to him. See jadaEa.
Oulozima XayoYFA laA yufaAriquhu [He was made to cleave to a thing, not quitting it]. (K.)
Oalozamahu AllRehu AlXRarRa May God make evil to cleave to him: or, to attend him constantly: or decree evil to him.

OalozamanaAhu TaAYirahu fiI Eunuqihi, (Kur xvii. 14,) We have decreed to him his happiness or his misery, foreseeing that he would be obedient, or disobedient: (AM, in TA, art. Tyr:) or we have made his works and what is decreed to him to cleave to him like the Tawoq upon his neck. (Bd.)
Oalozamahu AlbayRinapa He compelled him, or constrained him, to accept, or admit, the evidence, or proof. (Jel xi. 30.)
Oalozamahu AlmaAla He obliged him to pay the money &c. Oalozamahu AlEamala He obliged him to do the deed. (Msb.)
Oalozamotuhu AldRanoba, and AlHaqRa: see zakRa.
Oalozimo naEolayoka qadamayoka [Keep thou thy sandals upon thy feet]. (From a trad. in the Jámi' es- Sagheer.)

8. Ailotazama He took upon himself an affair. (KL.) You say, Ailotazamahu He took it upon himself; charged himself with it; obliged himself to do it; became, or made himself, answerable for it by an inseparable obligation: see baMCa.

Ailotazamotu baAlmaAli i. q. Oalozamotu bihi nafosiI, and takafRalotu
baha, accord. to IAmb, or taHamRalotu bihi, accord. to AZ; (Msb in art. kfl;) I made myself answerable, responsible or accountable, by an inseparable obligation, for the property: see Damina.
Ailotazama AlmaAla, and AlEamala, He obliged himself, or took upon himself the obligation, to pay the money &c., and to do the deed. (Msb.)
Ailotazamahu He kept, or restricted himself, to it; i. e. an action, or usage, &c.
And It was, or became, necessary for him, or obligatory upon him, to do it, or pay it, &c.; or to suffer it, or endure it.
dalafa liQlotizaAmiI He hastened to take me by the hand and embrace me: see dalafa.
AilotizaAmN i. q. luzuwmu maA laA yalozamu: see below.
10. Aisotalozamahu It necessarily required it or involved it.
lazuwmN One who keeps, cleaves, clings, or holds fast, much, or habitually, liXaIoCK to a thing: see an ex. in the Ham, p. 238, line 21.

luzuwmu maA laA yalozamu The imposing upon one's self what is not indispensable; or adhering to a mode of construction that is not necessarily to be followed: as in the following instance in the xuTobap of the Kámoos: wabalaguwA mina AlomaqaASidi qaASiyatahaA wamalakuwA mina AlmaHaAsini naASiyatahaA.
laAzimN Keeping, keeping close, cleaving, &c.; tenacious: and pertinacious.
laAzimN A thing inseparable from another thing: pl. lawaAzimu. (TA.) Such as cleaves fast; inseparable: as an epthet.
UisomN laAzimN: see jamoEN, as signifying “ a plural. ”
lawaAzimu Necessary, or inseparable, adjuncts, accompaniments, consequences, or results.
Oalozamu as syn. with OaqonaI in the prov. xalaAWuka OaqonaI liHayaAYika means Most preservative: see that prov. in art. xlw, and see qaniIa AlHayaMCa, and lazima XayoYFA.
lazonN: see Oasolafa.
lusolusN: see sulosulN.
laisolaisapN: see salosalapN.
mulasolasN: see musalRasN and musalosalN.

lasanN Chasteness, or perspicuity, or clearness, of speech, (S, Msb, K,) and eloquence; (Msb;) i. q. bayaAnN: or, as some say, the quality of speaking well: and chasteness, or perspicuity, or eloquence, of speech, and sharpness of tongue. (TA.)
lisaAnN of a sandal, The thing (hanap) projecting in the fore part thereof. (TA.) See misoradN.
lisaAnN The tongue [or cock] of a balance: see minojamN in the S and K.
lisaAnN In formation, news, or tidings; syn. xabarN. (S in art. Elw.) See a verse cited voce EulowN.
talasRunN: see xaliyRapN, voce xaliIRN
mulasRanN, (S,) or with p, (K,) A sandal long and slender, like the form of the tongue: (S, K:) or having the extremity of its fore part like the extremity of the tongue. (TA.)
3. laASaqahu He associated with him.

muloSaqN i. q. daEiIRN (TA;) as also mulaSRaqN↓ (TA in art. lsq) and mulasRaqN: (K, and TA in that art.:) or [a consociated alien;] one residing among a tribe of which he is not a member by lineage. (TA.)
mulaSRaqN: see muloSaqN.
liToliTN: see daluwqN.
liToliTN A she-camel far advanced in age, and having lost her teeth. (T, in L, voce kuHokuHN.)
miloTaAsN A pickaxe. (TA.)
1. laTufa It (a thing) was small, or little; (S, Msb, K, KL;) and slender, thin, or fine: (K, KL:) and elegant, or graceful. (KL.)
2. laTRafa It (a medicine) acted as an attenuant, and as an emollient.
laTRafahu, inf. n. taloTiyfN, [He made it slender]. (A, and K, art. HXr; &c.)
3. laATafa He caressed; treated with blandishment; soothed; coaxed; wheedled; cajoled: i. q. baArRahu. (S, K.)

laATafahu also signifies He spoke softly, gently, or blandly, to him. (TA.) He acted in a good manner with him: (KL:) manifested goodness towards him: (PS:) he acted towards him with goodness: and he did so, experiencing from him the same: (TK:) or rather, as syn. with baArRahu, he behaved towards him with goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances; or did so, experiencing from him the same behaviour.
4. OaloTafahu He gave him a gift or present. (TA.)

He showed him kindness, or goodness, and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances, bikacaA [by such a thing, or such an action, &c.]. (S, K, TA.) Often occurring in the latter sense: but OaloTafaha bikacaA, expl. in the S and K by barRahu bihi, may mean He presented him with such a thing; like waSalahu bihi.
See OaxolaTahu.
5. talaTRafa liloOamori i. q. tarafRaqa: (S:) see TabRa.
I. q. takalRafa AllRuTofa. (Bd xviii. 18.)
talaTRafa bihi i. q. tarafRaqa. (Mgh in art. rfq.)
luTofN Gentleness: graciousness; courtesy; civility: (S, &c.:) see rifoqN: and delicacy of flavour, &c.
laTafN A gift, or present: pl. OaloTaAfN. (MA.)
See laTafpN.
laTafapN A present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour; syn. hadiyRapN; (S, K;) as also laTafN↓, as stated by Z and others: pl. of the latter OaloTaAfN. (TA.)

laTiyfN Gentle, gracious, courteous, or benignant: and also subtle; knowing with respect to the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, affairs, or cases: in both of these senses often applied to a man. And Refined in manners, &c.
Obscure, recondite, or abstruse, language. (Kull.)
See Ham, p. 455.
Applied to a medicine, &c., Delicate: see sawosanN.
laTiyfapN A nice, subtile, subtilely excogitated, quaint, facetious, or witty, saying, expression, or allusion; a witticism; a quaint conceit.
[A nicety of language;] any indication of subtile meaning, apparent to the understanding, but not to be expressed; as [matters of] the sciences of taste (Euluwm AlOadowaAq). (KT.)
AlUiloTaAfu Self-pollution, by a woman: see jalada Eumayorapa in art. jld.
2. laTRama He slapped much, or violently. See TalRama, and see K, voce mulaxRabN.
laTomapN: see naTiyHN.
laTiymN: see naTiyHN.
laTiymN A small camel. (TA, voce EasojadN.)
laTiymapN see zawomalapN.
Small weaned camels. (TA in art. Esjd.)
luEoTapN: see EuloTapN, in two places.
1. laEiqa He licked (S, K, TA) his fingers: (TA:) he ate a thing with his finger [by taking it up therewith]. (Msb.)
miloEaqapN [A spoon; vulgo maEolaqap;] a well-known instrument. (Msb.)
laEalRa [May-be; perhaps]; a word denoting hope and fear. (K.) It governs the subject in the accus. case, and the predicate in the nom. See Ibn-'Akeel, ed. of Dieterici, p. 90; and see layota.
laEalRa, in its original and general acceptation, expresses hope; but in the word of God it [often] expresses certainty, and may be rendered Verily. (Jel, ii. 19.)
luEonapN A man who is much cursed. (TA in art. xdE.)
laEiynN The base, or lower part, of a raceme of a palm-tree. (TA in art. Ehn.)
laEFA, said to a camel when it stumbles: see taEosFA, voce taEasa: and see the first paragraph of art. Ewl, last sentence but one.
laEowapN A hunting bitch. (L, art. Eqd.)
3. laAgacahu i. q. DaAyaqahu. (TA, voce caAqanahu.)
lugaAmN: see an ex. in a verse cited voce taragRama.
lugonuwnN The sides, or adjacent parts, (AlnawaAHiI) of the lahaAp, impending (muXorifap) over the Haloq [or throat]; as also lagaAniynN: (JK:) see gunodubapN, and lugodN.
lugonuwnapN: see gunodubapN.
3. laAgaAhu He jested, or joked, with him; inf. n. mulaAgaApN. (A, TA.) You say, laAgaAhu fiI AlbayoEi. (A, TA, art. kys.)
lagowN, applied to speech, &c., Nought; of no account; (M, K;) unprofitable. (M.)
Alyamiynu AllRagowu: see KT, voce yamiynN.
AllRugapu The genuine language of the Arabs; which is the classical language.
lugawiIRN Of, or relating to, the genuine language of the Arabs. maEonFI lugawiIRN A genuine lexicological meaning.
lugayRapN A word of weak authority. (TA, voce jiraAb, et passim.)
laAgK: see maAYirN.
1. lafRa He folded, or rather wrapped; folded up, or rather wrapped up, or rolled up, a thing in another thing.

lafRa AlEaduwRa [app. He involved the enemy (in difficulty), or entangled him:] said with reference to war, and excellence of judgment, and knowledge of the case of the enemy, and the subduing him, with the infliction of many wounds. (L, in TA, voce Eamatahu.) But see Eamata.
5: see 8.

8. AilotafRa It (herbage) tangled; became confused, and caught, one part to another: (Msb:) or became luxuriant, or abundant; (S;) it (a collection of trees) became luxuriant, or abundant, and close together: (AHn:) [or thickly intermixed:] it (a thing) became collected together, and dense; (TA:) best rendered tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense.
AilotafRa and talofafRa↓ He wrapped, or enwrapped, himself in, or with, a garment; (KL, PS;) i. q. AiXotamala. (Msb.)
AilotafRa wajohu AlgulaAmi means AitRaSalato liHoyatuhu [i. e. The face of the young man became continuous, or uninterrupted, in its beard]. (TA.)
AilotafRa It (an affair) became complicated.

lafRN wnaXorN in rhetoric, [Complication and explication, involution and evolution; i. e., a construction in which two or more words are mentioned, and, after them, two or more other words, as epithets, &c., referring to the former. lfR wnXr muratRabN, Involution and evolution regularly disposed, is when the order of the latter words agrees with that of those to which they refer. lfR wnXr maEokuwsN, or muXawRaXN, Involved, or disordered, involution and evolution, is when the order of the latter words is contrary to that of those to which they refer]. (TA, passim.) See Har, p. 383.
lufRapN i. q. luqomapN: see SufRapN, last sentence.
lafRaMCu A thick thigh: see a verse voce tasaAhamuwA.
fulaAnN mino lafiyfinaA waDafiyfinaA: see art. Df.
lifaAfapN A wrapper for the leg or foot &c. (S, K.)
And A pericarp; a glume, and the like; an envelope: pl. lafaAYifu.
lafiyfapN A lock (xuSolapN) of hair. (S, voce xuSolapN.)
naAqapN mulafRafapu AlsRanaAmi [A she-camel having the hump much enveloped with fur: see AilotafRa wjohu AlgulaAmi]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, voce EulofuwfN q. v.)
mulotafRu Alxaloqi A man having a well-knit frame; compact in make. (L, art. msd.)
3. laAfaTahu: see faAraTahu.
AltRalafRuEu: see AXotamala.

1. lafaqa AlvRawoba He joined and sewed together, or put together and sewed, the two oblong pieces of cloth of the garment; (S, Msb, K;) and lafRaqa↓, inf. n. talofiyqN, signifies the same, and is more common; or has an intensive signification. (TA.)
See also Har, pp. 253 and 254.
talofiyqN↓ The bringing, or putting, together. (KL.) And The making suitable, or conformable. (KL.)
And The speaking, or telling, what is untrue, or false: (KL:) the embellishing [of speech] with lies. (Har, p. 254.)
lafaqa He felled (a seam or garment).
2: see 1.

lafRaqa bayona AlkalaAmi, (JK, voce rasRaga, &c.,) inf. n. talofiyqN, (K, voce tarosiygN, &c.,) He interlarded, or embellished, the speech, or discourse, with falsehood: see the pass. part. n. mulafRaqapN: and see rasRaga, and rabiqa, and ramRaqa.
5. talafRaqa bihi: see taOafRaqa.
lifoqaAni Two pieces which compose a mulaMCap, (Mgh, Msb, TA, in art. ryT,) being joined together, (Mgh, TA, in that art.,) by sewing or the like. (TA in that art.)
lifaAqN: see radiymapN.
OaHaAdiyvu mulafRaqapN Narrations, or stories, compounded, or combined, with falsehood; embel-lished [or interlarded] therewith: and put together. (MA, Har, p. 254.)
XuqRapN mulafRaqapN: see baiSyrapN.
lifaAmN A kind of woman's face-veil. See niqaAbN.

6. talaAfaAhu i. q. tadaArakahu [He repaired it; a meaning well known]; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a short-coming; or failing, or falling short, of what
was requisite, or due; and an inconsistent act. (TA.) You say, hecaA OamorN laA yutalaAfaI [This is an affair that will not be repaired]. (TA.) And talaAfaI Oamorahumo biAlSRuloHi [He repaired their condition by peace, or reconciliation]. (EM, p. 117.) See daqRahu
lafaApN: see lfaAtN.
laqRN A fissure in a rock. (AA, in TA, voce vatRN.)
laqRN baqRN and laqolaAqN baqobaAqN: see baqaAqN.
1. laqifahu He seized it, or took it quickly; (S, M, K;) namely, a thing thrown to him with the hand, or said to him. (M, TA.) See also last sentence of 1 in art. Hnk.
5. talaqRafahu mino famihi He caught it and retained it quickly, [i. e., what he said,] from his mouth. (TA.)

1. laqima luqomapF, [aor.
laqama
,] inf. n. laqomN, (JK, MS,) [He gobbled a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful, or] he swallowed the gobbet; and so AilotaqamahaA↓. (S.) laqimahu, aor.
laqama
, (Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. laqomN, (JK, MA, K, MS, JM,) or laqamN (Msb, [app. a mistake,]) He gobbled it; i. e., ate it quickly, (Msb, K, TA,) as also Ailotaqamahu↓, (Msb, [see above,]) and hastily; drew it with his mouth, and ate it quickly. (TA)
laqima biyadihi He put morsels into his mouth (i. e., his own mouth) with his hand. See an ex. voce raqaEa. This seems to be the primary signification.

2. laqRamahu AlTRaEaAma UiyRaAhu Oaloqamahu↓ [He fed with the food by the mouthful; put it into his mouth by the mouthful]: (Msb:) or laqRamahu UiyRaAhu and Oaloqamahu↓ UiyRaAhu he put a mouthful [of it] into his mouth. (TA.) And laqRamahu and Oaloqamahu↓ [He fed him by the mouthful; put mouthfuls into his mouth]. (S.)
4. Oaloqama He put morsels into the mouth of [such a one]. See 2.
Oaloqamotuhu AlHajara (assumed tropical:) I silenced him in an altercation. (Msb.)
Oaloqamahu AlbiroTiyla; see the latter word.
5. talaqRama AllRuqomaha He swallowed the gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful, in a leisurely manner. (S, TA.)
8: see 1.

Ailotaqama faAhaA fiI AltRaqobiyli [He took her mouth within his lips in kissing]. (S in art. kEm.) Hence the verb signifies (assumed tropical:) It embraced, or clasped, a thing: see an instance, voce miHoSanN.

luqomapN A morsel, gobbet, or mouthful: what is [swallowed, or] eaten quickly, at once, of bread [&c.]; like as juroEapN signifies what is swallowed at once in drinking: (Msb:) or what is prepared to be [swallowed, or] eaten quickly [at once]. (K, TA.)
luqomapN AlqaADiI, and luqomapu Alxaliyfapi: see zumaAwarodN, art. wrd; and muyasRarN.
luqayomaAtu AlqaADiI Same as luqamaAtu AlqADI.
3. laAqanahu i. q. DaAyaqahu. (TA voce caAqanahu.)
laqanN, arabicised from [the Persian] laqano [also written lakano]. A thing [or basin] resembling a Tasot, of Sufor [or brass]. (TA.) See UijRaAnahN.
1. laqiyahu He met him, or it. (Msb.)
And He [met with, or] found him, or it. (Msb.) You say, taloqAhumN OusodFA [Thou will find them lions]. (Mughnee, voce UinRa.) See also liqaMCN.
laqiytuhu and laAqayotuhu↓ I came near to him, facing him: came to face his face. near to him (Ksh, in ii. 13.)
laqiyahu bimakoruwhi (K in art. Hbh, &c.) He [encountered with him, or said to him, or did to him, a thing disliked, or hated: (TK in art. jbh:) like Astqblhu bimaA yakorahu.
2. laqRaAhu XarRFA [He made him to experience evil treatment]. (TA in art. jdE, voce jadRaEa.) See below; and see mulaqRFI.
yulaqRawona taHiyRapF They shall be greeted with prayer for length of life, or everlasting existence. (Bd in xxv. 75.)
3. laAqaAhu [He met him face to face; had an interview with him;] i. q. qaAbalahu. (TA.) See 1.
laAqaI He experienced pain &c. See an ex. voce dabirN; and voce MlN: like laqiIa, voce MlN.
laAqaI bayona TarafaI UizaArihi waXadRahu [He made the two ends of his AzAr to meet, and tied it]. (A, art. Hjz.)
4. OaloqaAhu He threw it where he would find it. (Er-Rághib.)
And hence, conventionally, He threw it in any way: (Er-Rághib:) he threw it on the ground: (Mgh:) [he put it:] OaloqaIotu AnmataAEa EalaI AldRaAbRapi I put the goods upon the beast. (Msb.)
Oaloqato waladahaA She cast her young one, or her young.
OaloqaI also signifies He let fall a thing, a curtain, &c.

Oaloqayotu Uilayohi xayorFA (assumed tropical:) I did good to him. (TA.) And Oaloqayotu Uilayohi AlmuwadRapa and baAlmawadRapi (assumed tropical:) [I offered or tendered to him, or gave or granted him, love, or affection]. (TA.)

OaloqaI Ealayohi raxamatahu (assumed tropical:) [He made his love, &c., to fall, or light, upon him, i. e. he bestowed it upon him]. (K, TA in art. rxm. [See this and three similar exs. voce raxamN.])
OaloqaI Uilayohi AlsRalaAma He offered to him salutation, or submission: see silomN.
Xaraba maA OuloqiIa Uilayohi: see art. Xrb.
Oaloqayotu Uilayohi Alqawola and baAlqawoli I told, or communicated, to him the saying. (Msb.)
OaloqI Ealayohi XaraAXirahu: see art. Xr.
OaloqaAhu Ealayohi He put it into his mind; he suggested it: AlqAh [thus used] is said of God and of the Devil. (Kull, p. 277, in explanation of AlfyD. [See 1 in art. fayoDu, last sentence but one.])
[And] He dictated it; (Msb;) namely, a writing to the writer. (Msb, in art. ml.)
OaloqaI UilaIRa sirRahu [He revealed to me his secret]. (TA, art. sr.)
laA OuloqiI Uilayohi baAlFA: see art. bwl.
OaloqaI binafosihi, said of night (AllRayolu): see rabaDa.
5. talaqRaAhu minohu He received it from him. (TA.)
talaqRaI i. q. talaqRana. (Bd in l. 16.)
8. AilotaqaI masolakaAhaA [Her vagina and rectum met together in one, by the rending of the part between,] on the occasion of devirgination. (M, in art. Atm.)
10. AisotaloqaI He lay, syn. naAma, (K,) upon the back of his neck. (JK, S, K.) And It (any. thing) was [or lay] as though thrown down or extended. (T, JK, TA.)
laqFI Muscles of the flesh. (TA, art. Dyj.)
laqFI baqFI: see baqaAqN.
liqaMCN The facing a thing. [encountering it:] and meeting it, meeting with it, or finding it: and perceiving it by the sense, and by the sight. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
liqaMCN: its predominant application is Encounter, i. e. conflict, fight, battle, or war. (Mgh.)
yawomu AllRiqaMCi The day of encounter in fight &c.
bayoEu UiloqaMCi AlHajari: see naAbacahu, and art. lms.

wajadotu hecaA mn tiloqaMCika I experienced this from thee, or on thy part; syn. mino jihatika and mino qibalika. (Mgh in art. qbl.) hecaA AlOamoru mino tiloqaAYihi This thing, or affair, is from him; syn. mino Einodihi; as also mino qibalihi and mino ladunohu. (Lth, in TA in art. qbl.)

taloqaMCa In the direction that meets or faces. (El-Khafájee, TA.) You say, tawajRaha tiloqaMCa fulaAnK [He went towards such a one], and tiloqaMCa AlnRaAri [in the direction of, or towards, the fire]. (K.) And jlst tiloqaMCahu I sat over against him, or opposite to him. (S.) And waqafa tiloqaMCa Albayoti He stopped facing the house. (Msb.)
tiloqaMCu Alqibolapi [The direction of the Kibleh]. (M, K, voce UimoAmN.)
See bayRanahu.
malaAqiI Alfazoji [pl. of maloqFI,] The narrow, or strait, parts of the pudendum muliebre. (TA in art. lHm.)

s.hi: The horizontal slabs in which is the aperture in a privy.

sense.s: mulaqRFI Greeted: see bulahoniyapN, in art. blh.
1. lkRahu He pushed him, or thrust him; like dakRahu and SakRahu. (As, TA in art. dk.)
likaAkN A pressing, or crowding: see an ex. voce EakRahN.
lakozN [inf. n. of lakazahu] i. q. TaEonN, like lazRN. (TA, art. lz.)

lukonapN An impotence, or impediment, or a difficulty, in speech or utterance; (Msb;) a barbarousness, or viciousness, and an impotence, or impediment, in speech: (S:) or the not speaking Arabic rightly, by reason of a barbarousness, or viciousness, in the tongue: (K:) or the interposing of [words of] a foreign language in one's speech. (Mbr, TA.) See tahotahapN; and EujomapN, with which it is syn.
lekino, with the n quiescent, has no government.
It means But after a negative proposition: but not after an affirmative: see UilRaA.
1. lamRa QllRehu XaEavahu God rectified, or repaired, and consolidated, what was disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, of his affairs. (S.)
2. lamRama He made a limRap of his hair. (Z, TA in art. jm.)
4. OalamRa biAlqawomi He came to the people, and alighted at their abode as a guest. (Msb.) See OaTaAfa.
And hence, OalamRa biAlmaEonaI (assumed tropical:) He knew the meaning. (Msb.)
And OalamRa baAlcRanobi (assumed tropical:) He committed the sin, or offence. (Msb.)
And OalamRa He, or it, visited covertly; (Ham, p. 23;) or in a light, slight, or hasty manner. (Idem, pp. 385 and 815.) It became near. (Msb.)
It happened. (Ham, p. 385.)
OalamRa bihi He came to him. (Ham, p. 127.)
I. q. zaArahu gibRFA; as also OalamRa Ealayohi. (TA.)
8. AilotamRa It was collected, accumulated.
lamo with an aor. following it is often to be rendered in English by the preterperfect: ex., lamo Oarahu mucu yawomaAni I have not seen him for two days.
lamo yaDoribo He did not beat. (S, &c.) See also lamRaA.
Oalamo: see the latter half of art. OalaA; and the former part of art. OamaA.

lamRaA as a particle of exception [is equivalent to our But; meaning both except and, after an oath or the like, only, or nothing more than; and] is put before a nominal proposition; as, Uino kulRu nafosK lamRaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [There is not any soul but over it is a guardian, (Kur lxxxvi. 4,)] accord. to those who pronounce the m with teshdeed: and before a verb which is literally, but not in meaning, a preterite; as in OanoXuduka QllReha lamRaA fEalota [I conjure, or beg, or beseech, thee by God but that thou do such a thing], i. e. maA OasoOaluka UalRaA fiEolaka [I do not ask of thee anything save thy doing such a thing]. (Mughnee.) See its syn. UilRaA. In the Kur xxxviii. 13, accord. to one reading, it occurs before a verb which is a preterite literally and in meaning.

lamRaA, accord. to Ibn-Málik, is syn. with Uico: [and sometimes, like Uico, it means Since, or because:] one may say, lamRaA OakoramotaniI Oamosi Oakoramotuka Alyawoma: but this is said to mean lahRaA vabata Alyawoma UikoraAmuka liI Oamosi Oakoramotuka. (Mughnee.) See also an ex. voce razaqa.
lamRaA yaDoribo He has not yet beaten. (S, &c.) See also lamo.
lamamN A slight insanity or diabolical possession; (Mgh, Msb:) a slight taint or infection of insanity. See TayofN.
lamRapN A touch, or somewhat [of a taint or an infection of insanity], from the jinn. (S, K.) See lamamN.
limRapN Hair that descends below the lobe of the ear. (S, K.) But see waforapN: and see a tropical use of it in a verse of Kumeyt cited in art. Hf, p. 597 c.
milamRN: see mivamRN.
mulimRapN A misfortune that befalls in the present world. (S.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce HajaA.
mulamRamN A boy having a limRap. (IDrd, TA, voce mujamRamN.)
1. lamaEa It (lightning, &c.) shone; shone brightly; gleamed; glistened. (S, Msb, K.)

lamaEa biyadihi, (K, TA,) and bivawobihi, (TA, S, K, &c., in art. xfq &c.,) and bisayofihi, (TA,) He signalled, or made a sign, with his hand or arm, (K, TA,) and with his garment, and with his sword; or did so for the purpose of information or warning; by raising it, and moving it about, [or waving it, or brandishing it, i. e., he waved it as a sign or signal,] in order that another might see it, and come to him; as also OalomaEa↓; but the former is the more approved; [i. q. Lat. micuit;] and sometimes the verb is used without the mention of the hand or arm [&c.]. (TA.) See a verse cited voce faroDN.

lamaEa bisayofihi, (S, and K, art. lwH,) and bivawobihi, (S, ibid, and S, K, &c., in art. xfq.) He made a sign with his sword, and with his garment, [waving it about, to make it seen by some one whom he desired to see it]. (S, K.)
4. OalomaEa biyadihi, &c.: see 1.
8. Ailotamasahu He sought, or asked, or demanded, it. (S, K.) He sought it out.
lumoEapN A shining, glistening, or glossy, appearance, [or hue,] of the body: (K:) any colour different from another colour [in which it is]; (TA;) [a spot of colour].
[Primarily] A portion of herbage beginning to dry up. (S, Msb, K.)
talaAmiyEu: see AboriyqN in the K, and my rendering in explaining the latter word, s. v.
lamaAqN: see EalaAqN, voce EuloqapN.

lano A particle denoting negation, rendering the aor. mansoob, and restricting it to the future sense: not implying corroboration of the negation, nor its never-ending continuance; though Z asserts it to imply these. (K.) [Hence lano yaDoriba signifies simply He will not beat: not he assuredly will not beat; nor he will never beat.]
lanojarN An anchoring-place, a harbour, or a port, (marosFI,) for ships. (TA.) Occurring in the K art. rsw. (TA.)
lahocamN A sharp spear-head: see an ex. in a verse of Zuheyr, cited voce zujRN.

lihozimapN accord. to different authorities, app. The
angle of the lower jaw: or the ramus thereof: or the flesh upon the hinder part thereof. See maHozuwnN.
1. luhiTa bihi He, or it, was cast, or thrown. (TA in art. xXf.)

1. lahifa Ealayohi, (inf. n. lahofN, S,) and talahRafa↓, He grieved for it, or at it; regretted it; syn. jazina and taHasRara; (S, K;) meaning a thing that had escaped him after he been at the point of attaining it: (JK, TA:) or he grieved for it, or at it; or regretted it; and was angry, or enraged, on account of it. (TA.) But see taHasRara; and see S, voce Oasifa.
tlhRf signifies He felt, or expressed, grief, sorrow, or regret.
5: see 1.
yaA lahofa O the grief! see an ex. in art. xTO, conj. 4.
4. Oalohamahu QllRehu liloxayori [God directed him by inspiration to that which was good, or to prosperity] (TA, art. wfq)
Oalohamahu UiyRaAhu He suggested it to him; (in the order of the words, he suggested to him it;) he put it into his mind.
8. Ailotahama He gulped.
laAhumRa and AllRehumRa: see AllRehu.
1. lahiIa Eanohu, (S, Msb, K) and lahaA Enh (Msb, K,) He became diverted from it, so as to forget it. (S, Msb, K.)
See an ex. voce AstOvr: and see Eano.
lahato UilaI Hadiyvihi, inf. n. lahowN and luhuwRN, She (a woman) was, or became, cheered, or delighted, and pleased, with his discourse. (M, K.) And so lahawotu biHadiyvihi. (T in art. rnw.)
4. OalohaAniI AlXRaIoCu The thing diverted me; syn. XagalaniI. (Msb.)
OalohaAhu baAlginaMCi [He diverted him by singing]. (S, art. smd.)
5. talahRaI baAlXRaIoCi i. q. taEalRala: (TA:) and OuwliEa bihi. (Msb.)
And talRihaI He diverted himself. (TA.)

lahowN Diversion; pastime; sport; play: or especially, such as is vain, or frivolous; idle sport: (from various explanations:) what occupies a man so as to divert him from that which would render him sad or solicitous, &c.: (TA:) or relief of the mind by means which wisdom does not require: this [it is said] is the original signification: (Et-Tarasoosee, Msb:) a thing in which a man delights himself, and which occupies him so as to divert him, and then ceases. (KT.) It has a more general application than laEibN: for ex., the hearing of musical instruments or the like is lahowN, but not laEobN. (TA.)
Mlapu lahowK [An instrument of diversion, meaning, of music]. (K voce rabaAbN.)
lahaApN [The uvula;] the red piece of flesh that hangs down from the upper Hanaki. (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán.) See also AlOasaAliqu, and XiqoXiqpN.

AllahuAp [generally expl. as meaning The uvula: or] what is between the end of the root of the tongue and the end of the qalob [thus in all the copies of the K that I have seen, an evident mistranscription for qalot, i. e. hollow] of the upper part of the mouth (K: [app. meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate; agreeably with the next explanation here following:]) or the furthest part of the mouth: [see gunRpN:] and, of the he-camel, the XiqoXiqap [i. e. bursa faucium]. (JK.) See also a usage of the pl., lahawAtN, in the last explanation of qalotN.

luhowapN What is thrown, [i. e. the quantity of corn that is thrown,] (S, K,) by the grinder, with his hand, (S,) into the mouth of the mill or millstone. (S, K.) And The mouth [itself] of the mill or mill-stone. (IKtt, TA; and S voce AxurRN.)
lawo: see maSodariyRapN.
It is used as an optative particle, liltRamanRiI. See Kur, ii. 162; and Jel, ibid. See also karRapN.
lawo kaAna hecaA lakaAna caAka Had this been, or if this were, that had been, or would have been.
SalRi walawo Eajazota Eani AlqiyaAmi means [Pray thou though thou be unable to stand; i. e.] pray thou whether thou be able to stand or unable to do so. (Msb in art. An.)
See also exs. voce OanRa, and balRa.
lawo often begins a sentence ending with an aposiopesis.
lawo meaning Oano: see wadRa.
lawo tusawRaI bihimu AlOaroDu: see bi as syn. with EalaI.
lawRN The word lawo: see a prov. cited voce canabN (near the end of the paragraph). And see sawofa.
lawo OanRa [If]. Ex. lawo OanRaka qaAYimN laqumotu [Hadst thou been standing, I had stood]. (K, art. An.) See Kur, xxxix. 58; &c.
lawolaA and lawomaA: see HaDRahu.

lawolaA faEalotu kacaA means Wherefore didst not thou such a thing? and lawolaA tafoEalu kacaA means Wherefore wilt not thou do such a thing? and in like manner, lawomaA and OlRaA and halRaA. See an ex. in the Kur, x. 98, explained in art. UilRaA.
lawolaA hecaA lakaAna caAka Had not this been, or but for this, that had been, or would have been.
lawolaA is followed by a noun in the nom. case (as in the Kur, viii. 69), or by a verb, as in exs. above.
laAta: see Oalata.
mulawRaSN The sweet food called fAlwc: see muzaEofarN.
lawoEapN Ardour of love: see HubRN.
1. maA EaAqato walaA laAfato: see 1 in art. Ewq.
lawiqN and layRiqN: see EawiqN and EayRiqN.

1. laAka He chewed a morsel: (S, K, Msb:) or chewed in the gentlest manner: or chewed something hard; (K;) rolling it about, or turning it round, in his mouth: (TA:) [he (a child) mumbled, or bit softly, his finger]: (S, art. mrv:) he (a horse) champed, (Msb,) or chewed, the bit. (Lth in TA, art. Alk.)
4. OalikoniI Uilayohi; and Oalakotuhu; as though from OalaAkahu: see art. Alk.
5. maA talawRakotu biOaluwkK: see Oaluwko.
1. laAma, inf. n. lawomN, He blamed, censured, or reprehended, syn. Eacala, (S, M, Msb, K,) a person, (S, Msb,) EalaI kacaA [for such a thing]. (S.)
4. OalaAma He did a thing for which he should be blamed. (S in art. jnf, and L and TA in art. ryb.)
5. talawRama i. q. takalRafa AllRawoma. (Ham, p. 356.)
laAYimapN A thing for which the doer is blamed. (TA.)
2. lawRana i. q. talawRana↓ It became coloured. (M.)
It (a palm-tree) had dates which had become coloured. (T.)
lawRana fiI AlkalaAmi [He varied in speech]. (Sgh, K, voce tamaTRaTa.)
5. talawRana It became coloured. (MA, KL.) See 1.
It became variegated, or diversified in colour.
And hence, (see tgRwl,) It varied in state, or condition; it was, or became, variable therein. He assumed various forms, or appearances.
talawRana fulaAnN Such a one varied in disposition. (Msb.)
lawonN Colour: (S, Msb, K:) distinctive quality or property: (M, K:) sort, or species: (S, K:) mood, disposition, or character.
OalowaAnu AlOaToEimapi [Sorts, or species, of viands]. (S in art. bOj.)
mutalawRinN Varying, or variable, in dispositions.
Unsteady in disposition. (K.)
1. lawaI Ealayohi He waited for him. (Msb.)
marRa laA yalowiI EalaI OaHadK He went along, not pausing nor waiting for any one. (Msb.) See the Kur-án, iii. 147.
lawaAhu bidayonihi i. q. maTalahu. (S, Msb, K.)

lawaI He twisted a thing; turned or wreathed it round or about: contorted it: wound it: curled it: curved it: or bent it. (K, &c.) And He, or it, turned him from his course; made him to deviate, or swerve.
lawaI Ealayohi He went round it, or round about it. (Bd, in liii. 20.)
lawaI Ealayohi Oamorahu [He mode his case, or affair, difficult and intricate to him: see UilotawRI Ealayohi]. (S, K, art. EwS.)
lawaI xabarahu, (assumed tropical:) He concealed his information. (T, TA.) And lawaI Oamorahu EinRiI (tropical:) He concealed his affair from me. (K, TA.)
4. OalowaI biAlkalaAmi He distorted, wrested, or wrung, the language. (M, K.) [Hence, perhaps, fulaAnN yulowiI bixaSomihi, if the verb be correctly thus: see EuqomiIa, last sentence.]
5. talawRaI It twisted, or coiled, itself: (KL:) it became twisted, or coiled: one says, talawRati AlHayRapu. (MA.)
talawRaI mino wajaEi AlDRarobi [He writhed by reason of the pain of beating]. (M, A, K, art. Dwr.)
6. yatalAawayaAni said of two serpents [They twist together]: see EaqAamN, last sentence.
8. AilotawaI, neuter verb, It twisted: wound: bent. (K, &c.)
AilotawaI Ealayohi It (an affair) became difficult; or difficult and intricate. (TA.)
Alotawato EalaIRa HaAjatiI My want became difficult of attainment. (TA.)
AltwI Ealayohi also He acted, or behaved, perversely towards him.

liwaMCN A banner, or standard, syn. EalamN, (M, Mgh, K,) of a commander, (T,) or of an army, less than the raAyap, being a strip of cloth, twisted, or wound, and tied to a spear-shaft. (Mgh.) See rifaAdapN. Respecting the liwaMC of the Kaabeh, see sadana and faAdapN.
sawRaMCN lawRaMCN: see art. swI.
AllRawaA occurs in poetry for AllRawaAtiI. (TA in art. Xrf.)
OalowaI Very contentious. (K.) See an ex. voce musotamarR.
Oalayosa: see the latter part of art. OalaA.
1. laAga, aor. yalaAgu, inf. n. layagN: see an ex. in a verse cited voce tazanRada.
liyfN [The membranous fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree:] the best sort is the lyf of the cocoa-nut. (TA.) See XariyEN.
liyfN is used by Ibn-Mukbil as meaning (assumed tropical:) A she-camel's tail. (TA in arts. Xcb and Xml.)
1. maA yaliyqu bihi It is not suitable to him, does not befit him, that he should do such a thing. (Msb.)
layokaA, [i. e. layoka with an adjunct alif for the sake of the rhyme,] for Uilayoka: see art. UilaI, near the end.
layolN: see nahaArN.
banaAtu AllRayoli Wishes: (T, TA in art. bnI:) and anxieties. (TA ibid.)
Aibonu AllRayoli The thief, or robber: (T in art. bnI:) and the wayfarer, or traveller. (Er-Rághib in TA in that art.)
Oaxuw AllRayoli A nightfarer: see a verse cited voce Eadasa.
layolapN A night-journey, or night's journey.
raOayotu AllRayolapa fiI manaAmiI; and kaAna kacaA wakacaA AllRayolapa; and maA OaXobaha AllRayolapa biAlbaAriHaho: see above, p. 183 a.
OumRu layolaI Wine: layolaI signifying AlnRaXowapu. (T in art. Am.)
layoliIRN: see nahirN.
layaAlK is pl. of layolaApN. (TA, voce OaroDN.)
mulaAyalapN from AllRayolu is like muyAawamapN from Alyawomu, and muXaAharapN from AlXRahoru, &c. (TA in art. rbE.)

1. laAna, inf. n. liynN [not layonN as in the CK] and layAanN, (T, S, M, K,) contr. of xaXuna; (S, K in art. xXn, and TK;) It was, or became, soft, as opposed to rough or harsh; smooth; plain; without asperities; fine to the touch; delicate; tender; supple; lithe; limber; pliant; pliable; flexible; ductile; malleable; soft, or flabby; lax: and he was, or became, soft; tender; pliant; gentle; bland; or mild. Hence lAn jaAnibuhu: see layRinN.
3. laAyanahu biAlqawoli He soothed, coaxed, or wheedled, him with words. (L, art. msH.)
laAyanahu [He acted gently towards him; (M, K;) treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed him; coaxed him; wheedled him;] i. q. daAraAhu. (S, M, Msb, voce dArAh.)
laAyanahu He was soft, tender, gentle, bland, or mild, towards him. (M, K.)
4. OalaAna baTonahu [It relaxed his bowels]; said of medicine. (K in art. shl.)
10. AisotalaAna: see its contr. AstxXn.
laAna for AloMna: see the latter in art. Ayn.
liynu AlEayoXi Softness, delicateness, or easiness, of life.
liynapN applied to a palm-tree: see art. lwn; and see EajowapN.
EayoXN layRinN Soft, delicate, or easy, life.
layRinu AljaAnibi: see jaAnibN.
layRinu AlOaEoTaAfi; &c.: see art. ETf.
mulayRinN A lenitive, or laxative, medicine.
laAhi Oanota: and AlHamodu laAhi: and lAahumRa: see AllRehu, and art. lyh in the S; and see an ex. of laAhumRa voce XaAdixapN.
